posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked:
I found a way to take input from a TI 84 Plus CE calculator, and feed it into the driver station. I have looked through the rulebook, and haven’t found anything that seems to prohibit using said calculator as a controller.

Here’s how it works: There is a C program running on the calculator (found here ) that takes the key inputs and sends them as keyboard keystrokes to any device attached through the USB cable. There is another program running on the operator console that takes keypresses and maps them to gamepad inputs on a virtual controller that the Driver Station can see and read. (program is here )

Does anyone know if this is prohibited during a match? I don’t really know too well what you can and can’t do, and as stated previously, haven’t found anything prohibiting it.

link_counts.title: GitHub - Powerbyte7/HIDeous: Turns the Ti-84 CE into a working keyboard
GitHub - luttje/Key2Joy: Simulate a GameController/Joystick using your keyboard and mouse.

posts.cooked:
Joshanson527:

Does anyone know if this is prohibited during a match? I don’t really know too well what you can and can’t do, and as stated previously, haven’t found anything prohibiting it.

You can use effectively anything you want as a driver station if it only communicates through FMS and uses nothing wireless and doesn’t do anything prohibited like confusing robots with weird vision targets.

posts.name: Justin Nesselrotte
posts.cooked:
Ah I remember back in the day with the TI-84+ SE, but all of our USB related stuff was z80 assembly!

The section you care about is 8.9 in the game manual, and the TI-84+ CE doesn’t violate any of those rules. So you should be good to go. It’s equivalent to bringing your own USB based control with arcade buttons.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked: Finally, a worthy replacement for the Logitech Attack 3.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
how soon until i can plot a path on the calc and then the robot follows it? image 1073×388 53.6 KB

image 1073×388 53.6 KB

image 1073×388 53.6 KB

When the Driver Station window is in focus, it eats all keyboard inputs so Key2Joy won’t work. I’m pretty sure this will be an issue with any software for converting keyboard inputs to controller inputs. If you’re tabbed in to a dashboard window or something else it should work fine, but ideally you would use some hardware like an Arduino to convert the inputs.

Not sure if this matters when using a TI 84 Plus CE calculator as a robot controller, but thought you might want to know on the off chance you ever field it (which you should absolutely do).

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked:
I eventually got it to work by modifying this program that takes over the calculator’s USB port and sends the standard HID keyboard report descriptor and commands. I designed a custom report descriptor so it shows up as a gamepad, and got one axis to work, as well as all the buttons. I’m currently working on adding another axis so it is interchangeable with an xbox controller so no robot program modification is needed.

I’ll post my code on GitHub when I’m done if anyone wants it! You can map any calculator button to any gamepad axis or button, and you can switch between 5 different control presets!

link_counts.title: GitHub - Powerbyte7/HIDeous: Turns the Ti-84 CE into a working keyboard

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: I don’t think the graph window would be very efficient, but I could probably design an editor like pathplanner. Wouldn’t be efficient but would be really cool! If anyone knows how pathplanner paths are stored then I could probably export the paths in a format you can implement!
